page.title: 16PHEASANT HATCHERY.
page.content: First wild phesants are caught, and have some feathers on one wing cut so they cant fly away.They live in enclosures surrounded by an electric fence to keep away the foxes, and are fed high protein food. There are 5 females to 1 cock pheasant. The eggs are put into an incubator holding 7000 eggs, which turns them all the time for 3 weeks. Then they are put into the still air incubator till they hatch. The chicks are put into an 'electric hen' which is warm, and they can go underneath it. When they are 2 weeks old plastic bits are put on their beaks; this allows them to eat, but they cant attack and kill each other. When they are 3 weeks old they are re- leased into the wild in the pheasant shoots. It costs Â£12 per bird to shoot.
